Color makes sad or happy,
Color makes many things praised or blamed;
In sum, color renders visible
everything in the World created by God.

10. Color, in nature, has marvelous powers.
One can find Examples in the case of
Pregnant Women, whose thoughts
imagined something such that they give birth to a child
who has this color: black, or something else.
we know this, and see it happen
that children’s bodies have birthmarks
of the same sort that frightened their mothers.

11. Similarly, when they are at times dreadfully
frightened by sudden profuse bleeding,
they give their children blood-colored birthmarks,
or abundant spots in another color;
or when some fruits or flowers
strike them in the face or elsewhere
at the beginning of their pregnancy,
if they do not wipe them off at once.

12. Thus is the power of Color manifested.
In this regard, we can draw on the story
of Jacob who lived in Laban, in the East.
because the effect of the colors came to him
when he laid down speckled sticks in front of his herd
in the rutting season, so that he acquired
goats, sheep, donkeys and other animals
with mottled and multicolored coats.

13. The capacity of colors is evident
in many ways among Birds and Beasts.
It gives them a noble and splendid ornament,
such as Tigers, Leopards and Panthers
who, among the jungle quadrupeds, without exception,
are pursued for their beautiful markings,
or for their sweet musk,
although they have to pay for it with their lives.

14. It would be a pleasure [to see] the colors
of the bird Phoenix, as Pliny describes;
In the same way one sees the Peacock parade,
making a wheel of its joyous colors
And turning it toward the Sunshine.
How beautiful is the splendor of the Parrot,
and the Pigeons, whose necks shine like gold,
and are called Columba in Latin.

15. Too many Examples would make
our present discourse too long.
Yet the heart rises from melancholy thoughts
